Award.AwardTitle: Estimating the Bayesian Phylogenetic Information Content of Systematic Data
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research will develop and test new analytical methods for estimating the quality and information content of biological data sets used to determine genealogical relationships (phylogenies) among species. Phylogenies are crucial in many areas of biology, from identifying emerging pathogens to studying the mechanisms of evolutionary change and the functioning of communities of species in nature. The methods to be developed in this research project will be announced in scientific journals, and will be provided in free, open-source software enabling researchers to apply the new methods to their own data. This project will also facilitate interdisciplinary training of postdoctoral associates, graduate students and faculty in biology and statistics. High school students will be involved in developing mobile apps that will provide useful, free tools to the scientific community.

The Bayesian statistical framework is widely used in phylogenetics and molecular evolution; however, the means for estimating the information content of data remains poorly developed. One reason for this may be the fact that marginal likelihoods and topology posterior probabilities are required for estimating Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergences, and accurate means of estimating these quantities have only recently been achieved. Correspondingly, primary objectives for this research are: (1) Evaluate the utility of KL-based information content measurement to answer a diversity of questions important to systematists, including: (a) How much information about tree topology is present in a data set? (b) Can topological information be separated from information about substitution model parameters? (c) How much information does one data subset have compared to a different data subset? (d) Do two data subsets contain conflicting phylogenetic information? (e) How much information is there about particular model parameters (e.g. a divergence time of interest)? (f) How much information is there for resolving particular clades? (2) Explore issues related to information content, such as: (a) a topological information content definition of saturation; (b) a KL-based method for estimating variable-tree marginal likelihoods for purposes of model selection; and (c) polytomy analyses. (3) Implement KL estimation of information content in existing Bayesian phylogenetics software to make it freely available to the systematics community. These objectives will be pursued using the variable tree IDR method to provide accurate estimates of all marginal likelihoods needed for KL estimation. The recently published conditional clade method allows accurate posterior probabilities of tree topologies to be estimated from sample conditional clade frequencies. Computer simulation experiments and analyses of relevant real world data sets will be used to evaluate the effectiveness of KL in measuring information content and in providing answers to the questions posed above.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Information is often described as anything that helps reduce uncertainty. Information can be measured by comparing the distribution of plausible values for some unknown quantity before and after information has been considered.

Bayesian statistics provides a perfect paradigm for measuring information content. The prior probability distribution explicitly defines the plausibility of all possible states before any information has been imparted, and the posterior distribution refines the prior based on information in the data. The difference between prior and posterior distributions provide an explicit measure of information content. A large amount of data may yield no information at all, in which case the posterior and prior will be identical. On the other hand, small amounts of information can yield enough information to eliminate all uncertainty. Information thus does not equal data.

We now live in the genomics era, where DNA sequnce data is plentiful. There remain many questions, however, about how much information is contained in those genomic sequences, and how much conflict exists among different genes or segments of the genome. Phylogenetics uses such sequence data (as well as morphological trait data) to estimate the phylogeny, or phylogenetic tree, of taxa (species or more inclusive groups). Phylogenetic trees are to taxa what family trees are to individual humans: phylogenies are genealogies, but at a broad historical scale. There is information about the history of a group of species in their DNA sequences. Just as a mistake made by a scribe in copying a manuscript in the middle ages would be propagated by other scribes using the flawed document as their template, organisms also copy mistakes in their DNA when producing offspring. These mistakes can be used (both in manuscripts and in organisms) to determine which copies were ancestral and which must have arisen after the mistake was first introduced. Estimating phylogenies accurately is of great societal importance because phylogenies make it possible, for example, to predict many features of an emerging pathogen just from its DNA sequence, allowing treatments to be devised well before the unknown organism has been fully characterized.

While genomics has provided much new data that can be used in phylogenetics, it is now clear that concatenating data from all parts of the genome from taxa of interest often leads to an incorrect phylogeny due to conflicting information. Different genes can argue with one another about history because they may actually have different histories (if some genes originated in unrelated taxa and were "horizontally transferred" into a genome), or they may have experienced differing forces that the statistical model being used is not able to fully accommodate. Regardless of the reason, it is important to know how much information about phylogeny individual genes carry and to be able to measure to what extent different genes are arguing with one another.

The purpose of this grant was to devise ways to measure phylogenetic information content in DNA sequence data and to ascertain whether different regions of genomes provide conflicting information. The accompanying figure shows a series of histograms that illustrate decreasing uncertainty as the number of DNA sites increases from top to bottom. With no data, each of the 15 possble phylogenetic trees for five taxa (A, B, C, D, and E) is equally probable (this prior distribution represents complete uncertainty about which tree is correct). With the information contained in 1000 sites, all uncertainty has been elliminated and all posterior probability is centered over just one tree (the tree shown).

Our major contribution was to provide methods for accurately estimating the amount of information about phylogeny encapsulated by the contrast between Bayesian prior and posterior distributions. We showed not only how to estimate the total amount of information, but how to partition that total information across different parts of the phylogeny. In many cases, there can be much information about one particular group but little information about there rest of the phylogeny. We also showed how to assess disagreement, which we refer to as informational dissonance, between different data sets, and show that total dissonance, just like total information, can be partitioned across the tree.

Our most recent work concerns how to measure information content and dissonance not for phylogenetic trees themselves, but for particular parameters of the statistical models being used in phylogenetics. It is important to use models that allow more information to be gleaned from the same sequence data and which arrive at an answer that is correct in spite of conflict among different subsets of data.

Broader impacts of this grant include a collection of four videos introducing Bayesian phylogenetics to those with little formal mathematical training (search for Primer at phyloseminar.org/recorded.html) and a tutorial on writing Bayesian phylogenetic software (at stromtutorial.github.io), as well as software for measuring phylogenetic information content (at phylogeny.uconn.edu/software/).
